joehung302 wrote:
> Would it have any impact for a large crawl? We're implementing this 
> using a "org.archive.crawler.deciderules.SurtPrefixedDecideRule".

It could; every SURT prefix consulted is kept in a sorted in-memory 
structure. (Specifically, a TreeSet.)

Each test of a URI involves looking up the URI's SURT representation in 
the list -- time complexity logarithmic with respect to the size of the 
set.

This lets the same lookup test for domain, exact hostname, and 
path-based do-not-crawl prefixes, all mixed in the same list. We've 
found that convenient for both operators and implementation.

But, a more efficient implementation is possible, especially if all 
do-not-crawl rules were always at the level of hostnames (allowing a 
simple hash lookup). We haven't noticed a bottleneck here (since 
switching to the sorted-lookup from an original linear-probe application 
of regexes) so haven't given it attention recently.

- Gordon @ IA
